content.text: Record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 1.1
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) .........\(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
Describe **one** technique to use so that the temperature reading is as accurate as possible in this experiment
The student pours an estimated volume of \(75 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A. He uses the scale on the beaker as a guide
He puts the thermometer into the water in beaker A and records, in Table 1.1, the temperature \(\theta\) at time \(t = 0\)
He records, in Table 1.1, the temperature of the water in beaker A every 30 s
The student repeats the procedure for beaker B
His readings are shown in Table 1.1
Suggest **one** possible source of inaccuracy in the procedure, even if it is carried out carefully
Table 1.1
Write a conclusion describing the effect of changing the size of the beaker on the rate of cooling of the hot water
Justify your answer by reference to values from the results
Students in other schools do the same experiment using identical apparatus
State **one** variable that they need to control in order to obtain readings as close as possible to the readings in Table 1.1
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x\) for beaker B
Use the readings for beaker B in Table 1.1 and the equation
where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Include the unit for the cooling rate
Another student thinks that more thermal energy is lost from the surface of the water in beaker B than from the sides of beaker B
Suggest an additional experiment that she can do with beaker B to test her idea
Suggest how the cooling rate of the water in beaker B in this additional experiment compares with the value of \(x\) in **(e)** if her idea is correct
A student investigates the cooling of water in different sized beakers
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1
Beaker A and beaker B have graduations as shown in Fig. 1.1
On Fig. 2.1, draw a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference (p.d.) across the resistor

parts.label: (b)

content.text: The student connects the crocodile clip to the resistance wire at the \(100.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the metre ruler and measures the potential difference \(V_0\) across the resistor
The voltmeter is shown in Fig. 2.2
Read and record the value of \(V_0\) shown on the voltmeter in Fig. 2.2

content.text: The student moves the crocodile clip to a length of resistance wire \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\)
Read and record in Table 2.1, the current for \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\), shown on the ammeter in Fig. 2.3
The student measures the current \(I\) for lengths of resistance wire \(l = 30.0 \text{cm}\), \(l = 40.0 \text{cm}\), \(l = 50.0 \text{cm}\) and \(l = 60.0 \text{cm}\)
Her readings are shown in Table 2.1
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the resistor
Use your value of \(V_0\) from **(b)** and the equation:
Suggest one practical reason why other students might not obtain the same result as this student, even if they do the experiment carefully
The resistance wire can become very hot during this type of experiment
Suggest one change to the apparatus that prevents this
A student determines the resistance of a resistor
She uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1
Draw a normal to point \(\mathbf{N}\), extending above \(\mathbf{AB}\). Label the upper end of the normal with the letter \(\mathbf{L}\)
Extend the normal downwards until it crosses line \(\mathbf{CD}\). Label the point at which it crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{F}\)
The student draws line \(\mathbf{EN}\) as shown in Fig. 3.1
On Fig. 3.1, measure the acute angle \(\theta_{1}\) between the lines \(\mathbf{LN}\) and \(\mathbf{EN}\)
(An acute angle is always less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
The student places a transparent block ABCD near the centre of the ray-trace sheet as indicated in Fig. 3.1
Measure distance \(d\) between pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\)
Suggest whether the two pins are a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing. Explain your answer
statement
explanation
The student places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) on line \(\mathbf{EN}\) as shown in Fig. 3.1
The student views the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) through the block

He places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) all appear exactly one behind the other
Draw a straight line through \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Extend this line to cross \(\mathbf{NF}\)
Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{NF}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{G}\)
Label the point at which this line crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{H}\)
Join points \(\mathbf{H}\) and \(\mathbf{N}\) with a straight line
Measure the length \(a\) of line \(\mathbf{HN}\)
Measure the length \(b\) of line \(\mathbf{HG}\)
Calculate a value \(n\) for the refractive index, using the equation \(n = \frac{a}{b}\)
Measure the angle \(\alpha\), where \(\alpha\) is the acute angle between lines \(\mathbf{RK}\) and \(\mathbf{GH}\)
Another student suggests that angle \(\alpha\) should be equal to the difference between angle \(\theta_2\) from (e)(i) and angle \(\theta_1\) from (a)(ii)
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to values from your results
statement
justification
The student repeats the above procedure for an angle \(\theta_2 = 40^\circ\)

He places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\) so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) all appear exactly one behind the other
Draw a line through pins \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\). Extend the line until it meets \(\mathbf{GH}\)
Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{GH}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{K}\)
Label the point at which this line crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{R}\)
Suggest one technique to use in this type of experiment to ensure results are accurate
A student investigates the refraction of light by a transparent block
He determines a quantity known as the refractive index of the material of the block
The student's ray-trace sheet is shown full-size in Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the speed of a small trolley moving down a sloping ramp
Plan an experiment which will enable her to compare the effect of different angles of slope on the average speed of the trolley between points on the ramp
Average speed can be calculated from the equation:
The apparatus available includes:
a long ramp with a support that enables it to be set at different angles of slope
• a small trolley
In your plan:
• list any additional apparatus needed
• explain briefly how to do the experiment, including how to take the measurements so that the average speed can be determined
• suggest a possible source of inaccuracy even if the method is carried out carefully
• state the key variables to keep constant
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
• explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan
